results.headline: Skewering the Status Quo in 'Another Gay Movie'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Another Gay Movie

results.summary_short: A spoof of teen sex comedies and gay coming-of-age flicks, this raunchy satire attempts to turn “American Pie” into “American Quiche.”

results.headline: 'America: Freedom to Fascism' Makes a Mess of the Mess We Are In

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of America: Freedom to Fascism

results.summary_short: Constitutional ambiguities surrounding the legality of income tax provide the springboard for this mess of a polemic about the mess we’re in.

results.headline: 'Little Miss Sunshine': You’re Either on the Family Bus, or You’re Off

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Little Miss Sunshine

results.summary_short: This bittersweet comedy of dysfunction takes place at the terminus of the American dream, where families are one bad break away from bankruptcy.

results.headline: ‘The Photographer, His Wife, Her Lover’ Explores a Marriage and the Art Market
results.display_title: The Photographer, His Wife, Her Lover

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Photographer, His Wife, Her Lover

results.summary_short: Paul Yule’s documentary wades through the seamy mess surrounding the estate of the Brooklyn-born photographer O. Winston Link, who died in 2001.

results.headline: In ‘Darshan: The Embrace,’ a Portrait of India’s ‘Hugging Saint’

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Darshan: The Embrace

results.summary_short: Less a documentary than an act of worship, "Darshan" is a glowing introduction to the life and work of Sri Mata Amritanandamayi Devi, the so-called hugging saint.

results.headline: In ‘Monster House,’ It’s Home Creepy Home

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Monster House

results.summary_short: One of the spooky archetypes of childhood imagination — the dark, mysterious house across the street — is literally brought to life in this marvelously creepy animated feature.

results.headline: Finding Magic Somewhere Under the Pool in 'Lady in the Water'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Lady in the Water

results.summary_short: M. Night Shyamalan's “Lady in the Water” is one of the more watchable films of the summer. A folly, true, but watchable.

results.headline: Alternatives to the Multiplex in 'The World According to Shorts'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The World According to Shorts

results.summary_short: For audiences exhausted by today’s bloated extravaganzas, “The World According to Shorts” is an eclectic palate cleanser.

results.headline: Dancing the Years Away in 'Been Rich All My Life'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Been Rich All My Life

results.summary_short: This admiring documentary portrait of the Silver Belles is a valuable historical footnote and a useful how-to movie about making the most of old age.

results.headline: In ‘My Super Ex-Girlfriend,’ Luke Wilson Is Just Not That Into Uma Thurman

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of My Super Ex-Girlfriend

results.summary_short: Uma Thurman does double duty as a New York neurotic, Jenny Johnson, and a secret superhero, G-Girl, in a shaky comedy directed by Ivan Reitman.

results.headline: ‘Clerks II’: Aimless and Aging in Slacker Paradise, N.J.

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Clerks II

results.summary_short: What makes "Clerks II" both winning and (somewhat unexpectedly) moving is its fidelity to the original "Clerks" ethic of hanging out, talking trash and refusing all worldly ambition.

results.headline: 'Boys Briefs 4': Six Films About Male Prostitutes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Boys Briefs 4

results.summary_short: A collection of short films of interest to precisely three demographics: programmers of gay film festivals, admirers of barely legal rough trade and connoisseurs of cliché.

results.headline: In ‘Shadowboxer,’ Murder Runs in the Family (and It’s a Turn-On in a Lover)

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Shadowboxer

results.summary_short: A gaudy thriller that leaves you with your mouth hanging open — partly in admiration of its audacity and partly in disbelief at its preposterousness.

results.headline: ‘Azumi’ Offers Sharp Sword, Short Skirt and Blood

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Azumi

results.summary_short: Adapted from the manga of the same title, this 2003 action flick tracks the blood-spurting adventures of a young female assassin who wields a lethally mean sword.

results.headline: ‘Mad Cowgirl’ Features a Kung-Fu Killer on a Mission or a Woman Who Might Just Be Crazy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Mad Cowgirl

results.summary_short: "Mad Cowgirl" is an underground movie with little sense of grounding, and lots of a multicultural weirdness and inchoate meat metaphors.

results.headline: ‘Overlord': In Wartime, a Brave Diffidence

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Overlord

results.summary_short: "Overlord," a prize-winning entry in the 1975 Berlin Film Festival, deserves to join the pantheon of essential World War II combat movies.

results.headline: The Search for Satisfaction in 'The Oh in Ohio'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Oh in Ohio

results.summary_short: A feel good movie about feeling good, this fresh and very funny sex comedy stars Parker Posey as a woman in search of an orgasm.

results.headline: In ‘Gabrielle,' It’s Getting Brutal for a Couple at Belle Époque’s Close

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Gabrielle

results.summary_short: Patrice Chéreau's startling drama recounts the dissolution of a marriage of a couple (Pascal Greggory and Isabelle Huppert) from the haute bourgeoisie.

results.headline: In ‘Changing Times,’ a Decades-Long Love, Reunited but Unrequited

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Changing Times

results.summary_short: Every character in André Téchiné’s rich, warmhearted exploration of cultural collision oscillates between two worlds and two ideas about the meaning of experience.

results.headline: Enlightenment Through Athletics in 'Peaceful Warrior'

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Peaceful Warrior

results.summary_short: As ludicrous as the title promises yet supremely unembarrassed, this new age enlightenment parable has its heart in the right place but a mind of corny mush.
